author: thenoetherprotocol
title: NOETH: Cardano for science in LATAM
description: 大多数PC用户平均花费20%的CPU处理能力。这对发展中国家的科学家来说是一种战略资源。

f6_assessments.q0: This protocol would create an incentive to invest idle computing power into scientific development.  Monetising computing power is something that is a solution to compensate a commodity that is in high demand in this day and age. The idea has high impact potential and could propel the world towards a better state through scientific advances. While reading the proposal I couldn't help but noticing the similarities with NuNet, part of SingularityNet. If forces could be joined,the reach of this could extend much further than Argentina or the entirity of LATAM. As a BOINC-computing power provider myself, this could revolutionise the way scientific research is being calculated today. BOINC has its flaws(computation and transmission errors as it runs through virtual boxes)  and with a financial incentive involved, it would also generate an incentive to improve the system.
f6_assessments.q1: As BOINC is currently not incentivised and the commodity that is offered by computing power providers is in high demand, a way of compensation will stir the market for sure. There are a ton of academic institutions, to just name one sector of them, that do this already out of altruism. If all the common households come in to mind the capacity increases exponentially, as it also does for scientific advancement. The protocol has a means to support itsself in the future by reserving a portion for hire in prospect of private usage.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal has been submitted in Fund 6 as well, where is contained a lot of auditable variables but did not make the vote. They have improved the auditability by adding a funding breakdown and additional information on the tokenomics in the attachments, improving this proposal by a large factor. But there is still no explanation of who would want to buy the tokens of the provider in order to make a profit. If this were to be solved, the outcome would be a near perfect proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: According to the proposal team, only 20% of the average user's CPU is utilized, and they intend to leverage it. As an Argentine citizen, I understand the frustration the scientific community goes through due to a lack of resources, and the fact that they are making the most of this project is impressive. To solve this problem, the team proposed developing a protocol that encourages users to lend their CPU power in exchange for native tokens. Although I agree that there is a clear alignment with the challenge. It is difficult to estimate the impact of the proposal as a result of a confusing definition of the metrics.
f6_assessments.q1: The team managed to assemble a comprehensive set of skills and experience and provided the necessary references to verify such qualifications. However, the development and implementation of the NOETH protocol are the most critical aspects of the project and it seems that this will entirely depend on the hiring of qualified personnel. It would be great if they already had a member in the team with the necessary background to have a successful implementation. I must congratulate the team for the excellent Tokenomics description of their project. On Catalyst, there are many proposals aimed at creating native tokens, but they make no effort to explain their logic to the community. The team is requesting funds to build a beta version of the protocol, the majority of which is to be spent on hiring developers. With respect to the values allocated, they seem appropriate to me.
f6_assessments.q2: The author does a great job describing the implementation milestones, which are organized into three phases. The author provides a brief yet effective summary of the actions that need to be taken at each milestone. However, with regard to the success metrics, the team could have done a better job. In 3 months it is stated that "LATAM scientific centers will be contacted to present the project and establish a collaborative relationship". This is more of a milestone than a success metric. In such a case, a suitable metric would be, "XX agreements are reached with the scientific centers." At the 6th month, the success metrics are defined correctly, with 3 scientific projects expected to use the network's computing power. Unfortunately, I would have expected a similar description of success in the 12-month milestone, but only the milestone of completing the first phase of the project is described.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem statement being majority PC users only spend average 20% of their CPUs processing power. This can be used as strategic resource for scientists in developing countries. The proposer wants to offer a token as a reward for lending the CPUs idle processing power. This proposal does effectively resolves the issue
f6_assessments.q1: Based on details provided on the proposal the proposer and their team have required experience and skill to execute this proposal successfully. The proposal contains a detailed plan on this will work and also about token working. Based on the information provided it is highly likely this proposal will be execute successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has given all details such as definition of success for 3, 6 and 12 months, A complete fund breakdown and also Estimated beta launch date so, with given info is sufficient to audit the development and the success of the proposal

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal sets out a clear problem and responds to the criteria of the challenge by proposing a solution for the Latin American scientific community, but not only, because the project carried out would allow a greater aim as it is stated: "The PC users do not necessarily have to be involved in any scientific community in particular, for they will be rewarded anyway in exchange for their idle processors. "It is thus understandable that the impact will be positive for the whole community. This also includes thanks to the explanations given in the KPIs. The emphasis was on explaining the project in detail and it is clear, unless I am mistaken, that there is no section clearly concerning the contribution of this project in Catalyst. But it can be understandable by all the information provided.
f6_assessments.q1: All the information concerning the participants is very detailed and allows to understand their skills and their consistency with the demands of the project, it is proven by links, all the explanations necessary to understand the basis of their thinking, their approach as well as the technical aspects, approached in an understandable way. All this information reflects a desire for transparency and therefore generates confidence. The budget seems reasonable and justified and the little note: "these are competitive salaries in Argentina, with more than reasonable purchasing power." is a non-negligible precision. The tiemline and the success indices are consistent and appear realistic.
f6_assessments.q2: What would be missing is a clear and identifiable description of concrete solutions brought by the team to communicate their progress to the Catalyst community. But overall, the information given is efficient and its success indices clearly identifiable and qualifiable with a time horizon for achievement estimated around August 2022.

f6_assessments.q0:
Excellent idea, clearly fits within the objectives of the challenge.
Although I would like to make a suggestion, the use of cpu power must have a cost for the user, but surely the cost will be a fraction, you can offer a much cheaper and more competitive service.
Once you create the organization, having a cost makes the service profitable ... in this case you could create a non-profit organization, finance through a selection mechanism (or with agreements with universities) projects scientific research.
If you only mint tokens with an unlimited supply, who will buy that token? Free for scientists that your organization transparently grants.
f6_assessments.q1:
I think the proposal can be built, but it needs to be refined to be sustainable over time.
The budget is reasonable, although you may need further financing. They have a roadmap and a good idea of what they want to build.
f6_assessments.q2:
They provide information about the people behind the project, making it possible to audit it. But you need a project website, with a white paper and a roadmap.
It is a good proposal, Successes
Greetings

solution: 我们提出一个协议，激励PC用户借出他们的闲置处理能力，以换取奖励，即NOETH代币。
experience:
B.Marcolongo: 物理学家-高性能计算
H.佩尼亚：数学博士--程序员
R.Sendín: 市场分析员
H.巴卡：律师--网络法
